The development of inexpensive solid-base CaO–MgO binary metal oxides (BMOs) as efficient and reusable heterogeneous catalysts was reported for the selective production of cyclohexanone (CyONE) from cyclohexanol (CyOH) oxidation under solvent-free conditions. These BMOs were prepared by ultra–diluted co-precipitation procedure and characterized by several sophisticated techniques, such as XRD, BET, CO2–TPD, FTIR, SEM, EDX, TEM, and ICP-OES. The crystallinity of the BMO samples was found from the XRD analysis and the estimated crystalline size range of the samples is 19.02–23.42 nm. The BET and CO2–TPD analysis of prepared samples gave information regarding the specific surface area and basicity (concentration and strength). The morphology and particle size of the 1CaO–1.5MgO sample were obtained from the SEM (61.8 nm) and TEM (55.2 nm) analyzes. Among all the catalysts, the 1CaO–1.5MgO catalyst displayed a higher conversion of CyOH (∼85%) with superior selectivity to CyONE product (∼90.97). The greater catalytic efficiency of the 1CaO–1.5MgO catalyst was attributed to the greater specific surface area, the smaller particle size of the MgO, the optimized composition of CaO–MgO (1:1.5), and higher basic strength along with a large number of basic sites. We have also optimized various reaction parameters including reaction temperature, time, catalyst weight, and solvent. Catalyst recyclability experiments were carried out to disclose that the catalyst has more robust, stable, and easily recyclable. The 1CaO–1.5MgO catalyst was very stable up to the 4th cycle. We also studied the spent catalyst characterization (XRD, BET, FTIR, SEM, TEM, and ICP-OES) to know the fundamental reason for the deactivation of the CM-4 catalyst. According to literature, CyONE is manufactured on a large scale with the (i) catalytic oxidation of cyclohexane through the formation of CyOH, (ii) hydration of cyclohexene, (iii) partial hydrogenation of phenol, (iv) oxidative dehydrogenation or direct oxidation of CyOH in the presence of an oxidant and (v) hydro-alkylation of benzene [1–5] Depending on the reaction process, the use of catalysts was demonstrated. Considering the various practical difficulties in the methods. The conversion of CyOH to CyONE via oxidative dehydrogenation or direct oxidation provides more opportunities to further scale up the manufacturing process by exploring appropriate catalysts. However, the catalytic oxidative-dehydrogenation of the cyclohexanol process may be restricted by thermodynamic equilibrium for practical conditions [6] Moreover, the catalysts investigated for this reaction are gradually deactivated through blocking of the active sites present on the catalyst surface by the side–products [7]. Therefore, the use of an oxidant was suggested in the direct catalytic oxidation of CyOH to suppress significantly the formation of carbonaceous species deposits on the active sites. Several types of homogeneous- and heterogeneous-based catalysts are reported for the selective oxidation of CyOH to CyONE [8–10]. Owing to practical problems such as recyclability and stability of homogeneous catalysts, heterogeneous catalysts are promoted as a suitable alternative to homogeneous catalysts [11–13]. A variety of heterogeneous catalytic systems including noble metal-supported catalysts, single/ binary/ mixed metal oxides, promoted oxide catalysts, zeolites, etc. are described in the earlier literature for selective oxidation of CyOH to produce CyONE product [14,15]. Li et al. prepared gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) encapsulated in the extra-large spherical cages of ordered mesoporous silica EP-FDU-12 for the gas-phase oxidation of CyOH 939 h−1 at 230°C and examined the particle size effect of catalytic activity [16]. Sancheti and co-workers have reported vapor phase dehydrogenation of CyOH to CyONE was carried out over monovalent copper using CuO-ZnO-MgO catalyst. The catalyst was prepared by co-precipitation CyOH conversion of 55.0% resulting in 99.2% selectivity of CyONE at 260 °C [17]. Nevertheless, the cost, preparation method, thermal stability of the catalyst, solvent for oxidation, use of the external base, and nature of the active sites of catalyst are the important concerns in promoting a suitable heterogeneous catalyst for selective oxidations [18–24]. Binary metal oxides (BMOs) are a class of heterogeneous catalysts, easy to synthesize, exhibits good thermal stability, and are found to exhibit good productivity and selectivity for the catalytic oxidation of alcohols including CyOH [3,17,25,26]. BMOs can be obtained easily from different types of metallic combinations with the periodic groups (for example alkali metals, alkali-earth metals, transition metals, rare-earth metals, or noble metals) via different preparation methods, viz., co-precipitation, wet impregnation, sol-gel, and solid-state mixing. A variation in the catalyst preparation method may provide different physicochemical properties and diversity in active sites that would be beneficial for intended catalysis [25–27]. Furthermore, BMOs can exhibit appreciable synergistic effects during catalytic transformation. We are interested to explore the catalytic potential of BMOs of inexpensive and earth-abundant alkaline-earth metals in organic oxidations. So far, these oxides (single or binary) are mainly used as catalyst supports for transition and inner-transition metal-based heterogeneous catalysts [28,29]. However, few reports disclosed the suitability of structural features of individual and mixed oxides of alkaline earth metals to function directly as main catalysts for certain organic transformations. They can catalyze all most base-catalyzed reactions. The arrangement of M+2 cation and O−2 anion and the surface defects are found to be crucial concerns about the catalytic efficiency of these alkaline earth metal oxides. As compared, their BMOs are thermally stable and surface basic strength will be superior to individual alkaline-earth metal oxides [30–32]. Herein we describe the catalytic efficiency of a series of inexpensive binary oxides CaO-MgO towards the selective oxidation of CyOH to CyONE in high yields in the presence of TBHP oxidant under solventless conditions. Synthesis of a series of CaO-MgO mixed oxides by co-precipitation method and their characterization by various analysis techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), BET specific surface area, Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT–IR), Scanning Electron Microscopy-EDX (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), CO2–Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2–TPD) and Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES) was performed. Reaction parameters like the molar ratio of CaO and MgO, reaction temperature, reaction time, the molar ratio of cyclohexanol to TBHP, structure-activity relationship between the basic sites, and catalytic efficiency were optimized. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and chemicals Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (Analytical grade, S.D fine Chemicals), Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (Analytical grade, Avra chemicals), NaOH (Analytical grade, S.D fine Chemicals) used were of laboratory grade, TBHP and Cyclohexanol (Analytical grade, Sigma Aldrich), India and we used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation A series of CaO–MgO composition-based BMOs with different mass ratios (2:1, 1.5:1, 1:1, 1:1.5, 1:2) were prepared by the ultra-high dilution co-precipitation method. In this procedure, the appropriate amounts of respective soluble metal salts of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, and Ca(NO3)2·4H2O were slowly dissolved in a minimum quantity of de-ionized water with magnetic stirring. This mixture was diluted with 1000 mL of de-ionized water for 1 g of the catalyst. Later, 0.1 M NaOH solution was slowly added to the above reaction mixture with magnetic stirring until pH=12 was reached. The obtained precipitate was continuously stirred for 24 h at room temperature and then aged for another 24 h. Thereafter, a precipitated solution was filtered off by Whatman filter paper under the vacuum pump and washed with deionized water several times to neutralize the products. The solid sample obtained was kept in a hot air oven and dried at 383 K for 12 h and finally calcined at 773 K for 5 h with a temperature rate of 5 K/min under static air conditions. As well, individual MgO and CaO oxide samples were also prepared by the same procedure. For our convenience, all the prepared BMOs in different mass ratios viz., CaO–MgO (2:1), CaO–MgO (1.5:1), CaO–MgO (1:1), CaO–MgO (1:1.5) and CaO–MgO (1:2) are designated as CM–1, CM–2, CM–3, CM–4, and CM–5, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The structural properties of the above BMO catalysts were studied with different sophisticated characterization techniques. The powder X-Ray diffraction (XRD) was collected using X–pert pro-X-ray diffractometer (P analytical BV, Netherlands) operating with a Ni filter and Cu Kα radiation source (=1.5406 Å) with a range of scan 2θ=0–80˚ at 40 Kv and 30 mA. The crystallite size of BMO samples was calculated with help of the Debye–Scherrer equation. The specific surface area of BMO catalysts was determined by a single-point BET analysis of the N2 adsorption isotherms using the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 device at 77 K of temperature through a thermal conductivity detector. Initially, all the BMO catalysts were subjected to heating for 3 h at 413 K to remove the physisorbed surplus moisture from the catalyst surface. A Micrometrics AutoChem 2910 instrument equipped with a TCD is performed to calculate the basic strength and concentration of catalysts using the CO2-TPD technique. Before the studies, the BMO catalyst is loaded and pre-treated in an inert gas flow (He was 99.9%, 50 mL min–1) at 573 K of temperature for 2 h. After pre-treatment, the catalyst was soaked with 5% CO2 at 373 K of temperature for 1 h, and afterward, the helium gas was passed through the sample at the same temperature for 1 h to remove the physisorbed carbon dioxide from the catalyst surface. This experiment was performed from 373 to 1200 K of heating in a helium gas flow of 30 ml min–1 with a heating rate of 10 K min–1. The IR results were obtained on an FT–IR spectrometer (M/s. Perkin–Elmer) at ambient experimental conditions using KBr discs in the scan range 4000–400 cm–1. For cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone adsorbed-FTIR analysis, the CM-4 catalyst was dried at 373 K for 1 h. The oven-dried sample (∼100 mg), was contacted with 0.1 mL of adsorbates directly. The adsorbed sample vial was kept in a vacuum dried at 393 K for 1 h to remove the physisorbed adsorbates from the catalyst surface. Then, the FTIR spectrum was performed with a nominal resolution of 4 cm−1 in the spectral range of 400−4000 cm−1. The morphology of particles was investigated by ZEISS EVO18 model Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), imaging at 40 Kv and 30 mA at a scan rate of 0.38 min–1. TEM images are recorded on a JEM–2010 (JEOL) equipped with a slow-scan CCD camera at an accelerated voltage of 200 kV. Before the TEM analysis, the BMO catalysts were ultrasonicated in ethanol solvent and placed on a copper grid and then the solvent was removed in a hot air oven at 353 K. 2.4 Catalytic oxidation of cyclohexanol The simple liquid-phase selective oxidation of the CyOH reaction was performed in a 50 ml of RB flask with a temperature controller magnetic stirrer under refluxed conditions. The RB flask was charged with CyOH (13 mmol), 70% aqueous TBHP (78 mmol), and 150 mg of catalyst (BMO or single metal oxide), and the mixture was stirred aggressively at ∼800 rpm in an oil bath. After each run, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation, and obtained liquid products were analyzed by a GC (M/S. SHIMADZU Instruments, Japan, model: QP–5050) equipped with a DB–5 MS capillary column and an FID detector. The used catalyst was washed with deionized water and oven-dried at 373 K for 12 h for further use. As shown in Fig. 1 , the peaks observed at 2θ values of 30.0°, 37.5°, 43.0° 62.5°, 75.45°, and 79.5° could index the cubic crystal system of CaO–MgO which is consistent with reported literature. The XRD pattern indicates that the peaks can be attributed to the MgO, Mg(OH)2, CaO, Ca(OH)2, and CaCO3 phases [33–36]. Interestingly, all the prepared BMO samples exhibited a dominant cubic phase of MgO. Our closer observation discloses that the XRD results of the BMO samples are broad and shifted to lower 2θ angles in comparison to pure MgO (2θ = 43.0°). The broadening of the XRD peaks can highlight the nanocrystalline nature of the BMO samples, which is more pronounced in the CM-4 sample. As well, the intensity of the CaO peaks was decreased in the BMO samples, which could be notable either due to the doping of Ca2+ ions into the MgO lattice or the amorphous nature of the calcium species. In addition, we also calculated the lattice parameter of the high-intensity peak of the MgO (200) plane, and obtained results are listed in Table 1 . Evidently, the lattice parameter was shown to increase after the incorporation of Ca2+ ions into the MgO lattice. These dissimilar results, like peak shift, variation in the lattice parameter, and reduction of peak intensity due to calcium species obviously confirm the formation of some portion of Ca2+ ion-doped MgO solid solutions. The crystalline size of MgO for each BMO sample was also estimated using the high-intense peak (2θ = 43.0°) in the XRD pattern by the Scherrer equation and the results are provided in Table 1. The crystallite size calculated from XRD data using the Scherrerۥ s equation was found to be in the range of 23.42–19.02 nm. The presence of different phases (metal oxides and hydroxides) led to the hypothesis that the CaO-MgO-based BMOs are capable of serving as effective solid-base catalysts for organic oxidations [37,38]. The calculated BET-specific surface area of all the BMOs and individual metal oxides (MgO and CaO) are shown in Table 1. The BET-specific surface area of the pristine MgO and CaO samples are ∼52.1 and 30.4 m2/g, respectively. However, the specific surface area of the CM-1, CM-2, CM-3, CM-4, and CM-5 samples was found to be ∼77.1, 81.4, 86.5, 97.6, and 88.6 m2/g, respectively. These results indicate that the BMOs have a larger specific surface area than their individual metal oxides i.e., MgO and CaO [39,40]. The single metal oxide particles may agglomerate to form bigger particles and display smaller surface areas. On the other hand, among the BMOs, the one designated as CM–4 with a Ca/Mg mass ratio of 1:1.5 showed a higher BET-specific surface area than other BMOs. This result indicated that the optimum molar ratio for the CaO–MgO was 1:1.5. Further increase in the mass ratio i.e., 1:2 resulted in a decrease in surface area. Fig. 2 represents the CO2–TPD experiment results of all the synthesized BMOs catalysts obtained in the temperature region of 323−1073 K. It may be attributable to the changes in the activation energy of CO2 desorption from the different basic sites present in the BMO samples. The estimated number of basic sites was listed in Table 1. The CO2–desorption peaks observed at 〈 473 and 673−473 K, and 〉 673 K are attributed to weak, medium, and strong basic sites, respectively [41]. The CO2–TPD results demonstrated the key role of the mass ratio of the MgO to CaO towards enhancement in the total number of basic sites (Table 1). Generally, the individual CaO oxide sample showed higher basic strength than the pure MgO oxide sample, and the mixed metal oxides of the CaO-MgO sample showed more basic strength in comparison to individual oxide samples. From the CO2-TPD results, the high amount of CaO present in the CaO-MgO sample exhibits lower basicity in comparison to the high amount of MgO present in the CaO-MgO samples. At higher CaO-loading, the BMO sample was easily agglomerated and formed larger particles, which resulted in the blockage of the basic sites. These results have well coincided with the BET-specific surface area and crystallite size of the BMO catalysts (Table 1). Hence, the total basic sites decreased with increasing in the CaO-loadings, but the strength of the basic sites of BMO samples is improved (Fig. 2). As well, at optimum CaO-loading, the BMO sample exhibited a lower crystallite size of the MgO and higher specific surface area due to the synergetic interaction between the CaO and MgO in the BMOs. Specifically, the BMO catalyst (CM–4) showed a CO2 desorption peak at > 673 K which is attributable to the strongly bound basic sites of the sample. The increasing basic sites of the catalysts are found in the order of MgO < CaO < CM–1 < CM–2 < CM–3 < CM–5 < CM–4. The BMO catalyst of CM-4 has the highest number of basic sites in which the mass ratio of the Ca: Mg is 1:1.5. The FTIR spectra of BMOs are shown in Fig. S1. The IR bands observed in the region of the 650–850 cm–1are ascribed to different vibrational modes of Mg–O, Ca–O, and Mg–O–Mg groups [42]. The band at ∼2340 cm–1 is assigned to the strong interaction between Ca and CO2 species. The band at ∼1750 cm–1 indicates the formation of polydentate carbonate with calcium. The typical Ca–O–Mg modes are assigned to a band at 860 cm−1. The broad IR band observed in the region of 3600–3000 cm−1 is mainly corresponding to the H–bonded hydroxyl groups. On the other hand, the IR band observed in the region of ∼3790–3634 cm−1 is due to hydroxyl groups from the surface of the CaO-MgO catalysts [33]. These hydroxyl groups play a key role in the improvement of basic sites of BMO catalysts. The IR band observed at ∼1100 cm−1 is assigned to the Ca–O stretching interaction. Further, IR bands detected at 1389–1470 cm−1 and 870 cm−1 belong to the stretching and bending modes of calcium carbonate species [33,42,43]. By SEM analysis, the information about the morphology and particle size distribution of the MgO particles in the CM–4 and CM-2 catalysts were obtained and shown in Fig. 3 . The SEM image of the catalyst indicated that the structural morphology of the synthesized CM–4 was slightly agglomerated particle with an average particle size of 61.8 nm, whereas the CM-2 catalyst was exhibited a bulky group of the nanoparticles with an average particle size of 69.9 nm. This image represents a lump of organized grains. The analysis gives information regarding the dimension of the grains to be in the order of a hundred nanometres [44–46]. TEM analysis was also carried out to investigate the structural evolution of the BMO at the atomic level and obtained images were represented in Fig. 4 . It was difficult to estimate the particle size of BMOs from TEM images because they were prepared by the precipitation procedure without a protective agent. We have estimated the average particle size of the CM-4 and CM-2 catalysts. The TEM images of the CM–4 and CM-2 samples indicate that most grains exhibit irregular shapes with an average particle size of 55.2 and 63.8 nm, respectively, which is consistent with the result of the XRD and BET analysis. 3.2 Catalytic activity studies 3.2.1 Catalysts screening test The selective catalytic oxidation of CyOH was performed over BMO (CaO–MgO) catalysts under solvent-free conditions in the batch reactor and the results obtained are presented in Fig. 5 (Scheme 1 ). The oxidative conversion results obtained with single metal oxides under solvent-free conditions are included. Results of oxidation conducted in organic solvents are discussed separately in the next sections (3.2.6). In each experiment, 13 mmol of cyclohexanol, 78 mmol of TBHP, 413 K of reaction temperature, 10 wt.% of catalyst (BMO or pure MgO or CaO) concerning cyclohexanol, 15 h of reaction time, and ∼800 rpm of stirring speed is used as standard characteristics under solvent-free conditions. In Fig. 5, the individual MgO and CaO metal oxide catalysts showed lower conversion of CyOH (56.3 and 52.0%) with selective toward the CyONE (55.0 and 57.9%) product, respectively. On the other hand, the BMOs composed of various mass ratios of MgO and CaO catalysts have shown a higher conversion of CyOH and selectivity towards CyONE product in comparison to that of individual single metal oxide catalysts. Among all the BMO catalysts, the CM–4 catalyst exhibited superior catalytic efficiency due to the greater specific surface area, optimal CaO–MgO composition (1:1.5), and a large number of basic sites. Therefore, the concentration and strength of the basic sites are played a significant role in the selective transformation of CyOH to CyONE. The CyOH conversions were found to be 52.06, 68.46, 70.56, 75.21, 85.36, 77.58, 56.36%, and the selectivity of CyONE towards 55.05, 68.5, 70.54, 79.37, 90.97, 81.25, 57.92% for the CaO, CM–1, CM–2, CM–3, CM–4, CM–5, MgO, catalysts, respectively. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature In each catalytic reaction, the reaction temperature has played a significant role because the rate constants are significantly influenced by the reaction temperature. The effect of temperature on CyOH oxidation reaction was investigated at different temperatures of 333, 353, 373, 393, 413, and 433 K over CM–4 catalysts, and remain conditions were kept constant (Fig. 6 ). There was no conversion of CyOH between RT to 313 K. By increasing temperature from 313 to 333 K, lower conversion of CyOH ∼27% with ∼99% of selectivity towards CyONE was noticed. However, when the oxidation experiment was monitored at four different temperatures 353, 373, 393, and 413 K, the conversion of CyOH was increased gradually but no considerable change in the selectivity of CyONE. It is also noticeable that when the temperature was further increased to 433 K, the selectivity towards CyONE was reduced, possibly due to the over oxidation of CyOH to produce the by-products. Moreover, higher reaction rates were attained at a high reaction temperature of 433 K. This observation reveals the activation of various basic sites at higher reaction temperatures excluding the main active sites producing CyONE. These activated basic sites become responsible for the production of various side products, such as cyclohexenone, ɛ–caprolactone, and adipic acid as by-products [7,20,47,48]. Therefore, the reaction temperature of 413 K with the maximum yield of the desired product was measured as the optimum temperature to study the oxidation reaction. 3.2.3 Effect of reaction time Reaction time was also considered another important reaction parameter in CyOH oxidation that improved the yield of CyONE. The reaction times varied between 1 and 18 h and the obtained results are represented in Fig. 7 . The CyOH conversion rate was observed as 9.1% and selectivity 98.5% at 1 h, whereas the reaction time was raised to 15 h, then the conversion rate increased significantly. Further increase in reaction time (>15 h) resulted in a decrease in selectivity to 71.2%. This may be due to the over-oxidation of the CyONE in the presence of TBHP taking place to produce by-products with a longer reaction time. Therefore, 15 h of reaction time is observed as optimum reaction time to produce selectively the CyONE. 3.2.4 Influence of cyclohexanol/TBHP molar ratio Fig. 8 illustrates the oxidation of CyOH reaction examined over CM–4 BMO catalyst at various molar ratios of the substrate to oxidant from 1:0 to 1:12. There was no oxidation when this reaction was carried out in the absence of the oxidant. As we increase the molar ratio of CyOH to TBHP to 1:6, the CyOH conversion increased gradually without a significant decrease in the selectivity of the CyONE product. However, when the substrate to oxidant ratio was increased to 1:12, a decrease in the selectivity was noticed without considerable change in conversion. This observation also supports the over-oxidation of CyOH at higher CyOH/TBHP molar ratios. 3.2.5 Effect of catalyst loading The influence of catalyst loading on the catalytic oxidation of CyOH to CyONE was investigated (Fig. 9 ). These reactions were carried out using a high-performance CM–4 catalyst at 413 K, 1:6 molar ratio of CyOH to TBHP, 15 h of reaction time, and 800 rpm of stirring speed. As the catalyst loading increased from 75 mg to 150 mg, the conversion also enhanced from 37.3% to 91.4%, whereas the selectivity decreased from 98.1 to 91.3%. This observation reveals that there is an increase in the number of catalytically active sites present on the catalyst surface. Further, an increase in the catalyst loading to 200 mg has led to a drastic decrease in the selectivity of CyONE (Fig. 9). This phenomenon indicates that as the catalyst loading increases, the residence time of CyOH on the surface of the catalyst also improves and favors the over oxidation to by-products (cyclohexenone, ɛ–caprolactone, adipic acid) and resulting in decreased CyONE selectivity. Therefore, a catalyst loading of 150 mg resulted in 83.2% of conversion, and 90.1% of selectivity was considered the best choice for this reaction. 3.2.6 Effect of solvent We have also investigated the influence of organic solvents such as acetonitrile, and ethanol on the oxidation of CyOH over CM–4 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 10 , the effect of solvent on the conversion of CyOH is minimal, but slightly changed in the selectivity of the desired product. These results indicate that there is no significant variation in the activity performance of the catalyst in the presence and absence of the solvent. Therefore, we propose that this oxidation reaction under solvent-free conditions over the CM–4 catalyst is advantageous. 3.2.7 Structure-activity relationship We have shown the important role of specific surface area and surface basic sites in catalyzing the oxidation of CyOH reaction (Fig. 11 ). The nature of the active catalytic site was determined by the CO2–TPD technique. The optimum amount of MgO in the CaO–MgO-based BMO catalyst indicates the beneficial effect of increasing the number of basic sites on the catalyst surface. Fig. 11 clearly shows a clear correlation between the increasing trend of catalytic activity and the order of increasing basic sites and the specific surface area of the catalysts studied. The concentration and strength of the basic sites of the synthesized catalyst are in the order of CM–1 〈 CM–2 < CM–3 < CM–5 〉 CM–4. These results demonstrate the important role of basic sites of the catalyst in the selective oxidation of CyOH reaction. 3.2.8 Plausible reaction mechanism Generally, the liquid-phase alcohol oxidation reactions could be examined under the various types of solvents, such as aqueous, organic, and solvent-free. Irrespective of the solvent environment used, the key rate-determining step is commonly recognized to be the activation C–H bond on the accompanying α–carbon, even though few reports have shown the initial dissociation of the alcohol molecule also controls the rate. As per previous reports, the proposed reaction mechanism for the oxidation of alcohol using peroxides (i.e., TBHP or H2O2) as oxidants over the solid catalysts, involved radical intermediates [49]. On the other hand, the TBHP is adsorbed on the catalyst surface to form the active peroxide-metal oxide as an intermediate, which can easily oxidize the alcohol functional group in the substrate and return to the TBHP [50–52] .Owing to these reports, it was found that the addition of scavengers has no considerable effect on product distribution over solid catalysts. Mainly, the catalytic oxidation of alcohol proceeds in three steps: i) the dissociative adsorption of the alcohol moiety on the catalyst surface to produce a surface alkoxy intermediate; ii) activation of the C–H bond on the accompanying α–carbon of alcohol to form carbonyl product and iii) desorption of the carbonyl compound from the catalyst surface and produce fresh catalyst [11,20,53]. We made efforts to retrieve a plausible reaction mechanism for the catalytic oxidation of CyOH to CyONE over the CaO–MgO-based BMO catalyst (Scheme 2 ). Initially, the TBHP oxidant adsorbs on the BMO catalyst surface to produce a peroxide ion (–OOH). Then, the reaction can be initiated through the O–H bond interaction of CyOH with surface basic sites (i.e., surface hydroxyl groups) present on the CaO–MgO catalyst, which will produce the alkoxide ion of the CyOH [54]. The peroxide ion then interacts with the alkoxide of the CyOH on the catalyst surface to form six-membered transition states. In the next step, the tertiary butyl alcohol desorption takes place from the catalyst surface. Finally, the desired CyONE product can desorb from the catalyst surface along with H2O molecules followed by the regeneration of the fresh catalyst. Therefore, the concentration and strength of the basic sites play a key role to produce a high yield of CyONE in the oxidation of CyOH. This observation suggests that the mechanism involves the TBHP activation by CaO-MgO active center to produce a peroxy intermediate. Yet, the exact mechanism of this reaction is not clear and the role of the catalyst should be further required to investigate in detail. We also performed the FTIR spectra of adsorbed reactant and product on the catalyst surface and the results are shown in Fig. 13C. The adsorption study of CyOH and CyONE on CM-4 catalyst at room temperature has displayed a series of IR bands at ∼1064, 1165, 1325, 1582, 1712, 2867, 2937, 3258 cm−1 and corresponding information is given in Table 3. From these analyzes, FTIR spectra of CyONE adsorbed on the catalyst surface were shown a sharp peak at ∼1750 cm−1, which is attributed to the existence of the ketone functional group (C=O) on the catalyst surface. The CyOH adsorbed FTIR spectrum of catalyst exhibit a distinct broad peak between 3500 and 3050 cm−1, which is due to the OH stretching vibrational frequencies of the CyOH on the catalyst surface. The CH stretching vibrational frequencies of adsorbed catalyst were found between 2950 and 2850 cm−1, which is corresponding to the saturated hydrocarbon without any double or triple bond in both cases. 3.2.9 Catalytic oxidation of different alcohols To explore the substrate scope and wider applicability of the catalyst, a series of structurally diverse aromatic primary and secondary alcohols were subjected to oxidation over a high-performance CM-4 catalyst under the optimized reaction conditions. The TBHP-mediated oxidation of different alcohols has various substituents, such as -CH3, –OCH3, -OH, -NO2, -Cl, -Br, etc. The obtained results are represented in Table 2 . As we clearly see from Table 2, we found that various substituents (electron-withdrawing and donating groups) played a key role in the conversion and selectivity of products. The electron-donating groups on the alcohol showed improved CyOH conversion and enhanced selectivity of CyONE product whereas electron-withdrawing groups on the alcohol exhibited diminishing conversion and selectivity of compounds. This can be explained by the fact that the electron-donating groups increases the electron density at the -OH group of the compound and easily produces the alkoxide ion of the CyOH, then activation of the C–H bond on the accompanying α–carbon of alcohol to form carbonyl functional group. In case of the presence of electron-withdrawing group on the alcohol, decreases the electron density on the oxygen of the -OH group and then it does not form alkoxide ion easily from alcohols [entry 3–13]. In general, electron density on the aromatic ring is important in the oxidation reaction, electron-donating groups increase electron density on the benzyl ring and vice versa. The slight improvement of conversion and selectivity in halogen at para-position than ortho-position this probably due to the positive resonance effect of halide groups at para-position, activating the benzene ring [entry 9,11]. Steric hindrance (ortho-effect) is another important factor that affects the reactivity as -NO2 and -Br groups attached to the aromatic ring at ortho-position decreased the efficiency of the reaction [entry 3,11,12]. Secondary benzylic alcohols are also converted to corresponding aldehydes with high selectivity [entry 14,15] [52,55,56]. 3.2.10 Reusability To understand the robustness and recyclability, we have carried out the selective oxidation of CyOH over high-performance CM-4 catalyst up to 5th cycles at optimized reaction conditions, and obtained data are presented in Fig. 12 . The CM–4 catalysts can be reused for up to 5 catalytic runs. After each run, the heterogeneous CM-4 catalyst recovered, washed several times with methanol to eliminate the substrate or product remains from the catalyst surface and pre-activated the catalyst at 423 K for 2 h in the hot air oven. As we clearly noticed from Fig. 12, there is no considerable decrease was observed in the CyOH conversion and CyONE selectivity up to the 4th cycle. In the 5th cycle, the catalytic efficiency of the CM–4 solid base catalyst was drastically reduced, and 55.83% of CyOH conversion was obtained. This could be due to the deactivation of the CM-4 catalyst after the 4th cycle. We have used the data of some characterization techniques (XRD, BET, CO2-TPD, FTIR, SEM, and TEM) to comprehend the physicochemical properties that are responsible for the deactivation of the CM-4 catalyst after the 4th run. The obtained physicochemical properties of the spent catalyst are listed in Table 1. The XRD pattern of the spent CM-4 catalyst indicates that the intensities of the various phases are drastically changed. As noticed in Fig. 13 A, the intensity of MgO peaks was significantly lower in comparison with Ca(OH)2 peaks in the spent catalyst. These results indicated the considerable variation in the crystallinity of the metal oxides of the catalyst during the reaction. This variation in the crystallinity of the metal oxides may be explained by the incorporated Ca2+ ions left from the MgO lattice to form the Ca(OH)2 phases. The average crystallite size of the MgO was increased (31.51 nm) in the spent catalyst. The BET-specific surface area of the spent CM-4 catalyst was significantly decreased (63.2 m2/g) after the 4th cycle of the reaction, which is in well-agreement with the SEM, TEM, and XRD results of the spent catalyst. The CO2-TPD profile provides information regarding the number of basic sites in the spent catalyst (Fig. 13B and Table 1). The spent catalyst significantly reduced the basic sites with strength, which may be due to either a decrease in BET surface area or strongly adsorbed CyONE species on the catalyst surface (Fig. 13B) and increased crystallite size of the MgO and CaO species. The FTIR spectrum of the spent catalyst clearly shows that the adsorbed species are strongly interacting with active sites of the catalyst surface (Fig. 13C). Fig. S3 shows the SEM images of the fresh and spent CM-4 catalyst. It showed that the spent catalyst exhibited agglomerated bulk MgO particles with sizes of 82.3 nm, indicating the sintering of the nanoparticles took place during the reaction (after the 4th run). The TEM images also suggest that the spent CM-4 catalyst displayed bigger particles after the 4th cycle. The average particle size of the MgO species increased in the spent catalyst (∼ 67.9 nm). We also performed the ICP-OES analysis of the spent catalyst, and the reaction mixture showed that the catalyst was leaching by 8.4 wt% by both metal ions after the 4th run. Based on the above aforementioned, variations in the physicochemical properties of the spent CM-4 catalyst are a fundamental reason for the deactivation of the catalyst after 4th run. We have performed all these characterization techniques under ex-situ conditions. 3.2.11 Comparison of CaO-MgO with reported catalysts In this mini-comparison study, we summarize the various catalysts and optimized conditions for the oxidation of CyOH to CyONE under liquid and vapor phases (Table 4 ). In this present work, we synthesized a CaO-MgO binary mixed metal oxide catalyst in a simple precipitation technique for solvent-free oxidation of CyOH and the catalyst demonstrated relatively high activity with other catalysts. 4 Conclusion The CaO-MgO binary metal oxides displayed excellent catalytic performance in the solvent-free oxidation of CyOH selectively to produce CyONE. These alkaline earth metal oxide composites are good solid-base catalysts and hence no external base is needed for this reaction. Among all the catalysts, the CM–4 catalyst exhibited higher conversion of CyOH (∼85%) with superior selectivity toward CyONE product (∼92%). The greater catalytic efficiency of the CM–4 catalysts is attributed to the greater specific surface area, the smaller particle size of the MgO, the optimized composition of CaO–MgO (1:1.5), and higher basic strength along with a large number of basic sites. The basic sites have played a key role in the alcohol deprotonation and activation of the C–H bond on the accompanying α–carbon of the alcohol. The high catalyst stability was estimated by performing catalyst recyclability experiments and the catalytic efficiency was unchanged up to the 4th cycle. Finally, we made some effort to comprehend the variation in the physicochemical properties (surface area, particle size, and basic sites) that are responsible for the deactivation of the CM-4 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The development of inexpensive solid-base CaO–MgO binary metal oxides (BMOs) as efficient and reusable heterogeneous catalysts was reported for the selective production of cyclohexanone (CyONE) from cyclohexanol (CyOH) oxidation under solvent-free conditions. These BMOs were prepared by ultra–diluted co-precipitation procedure and characterized by several sophisticated techniques, such as XRD, BET, CO2–TPD, FTIR, SEM, EDX, TEM, and ICP-OES. The crystallinity of the BMO samples was found from the XRD analysis and the estimated crystalline size range of the samples is 19.02–23.42 nm. The BET and CO2–TPD analysis of prepared samples gave information regarding the specific surface area and basicity (concentration and strength). The morphology and particle size of the 1CaO–1.5MgO sample were obtained from the SEM (61.8 nm) and TEM (55.2 nm) analyzes. Among all the catalysts, the 1CaO–1.5MgO catalyst displayed a higher conversion of CyOH (∼85%) with superior selectivity to CyONE product (∼90.97). The greater catalytic efficiency of the 1CaO–1.5MgO catalyst was attributed to the greater specific surface area, the smaller particle size of the MgO, the optimized composition of CaO–MgO (1:1.5), and higher basic strength along with a large number of basic sites. We have also optimized various reaction parameters including reaction temperature, time, catalyst weight, and solvent. Catalyst recyclability experiments were carried out to disclose that the catalyst has more robust, stable, and easily recyclable. The 1CaO–1.5MgO catalyst was very stable up to the 4th cycle. We also studied the spent catalyst characterization (XRD, BET, FTIR, SEM, TEM, and ICP-OES) to know the fundamental reason for the deactivation of the CM-4 catalyst.
